item.title: Suspect in Colorado Attack Criminally Charged by US Prosecutors
item.description: The man arrested over an attack at an event in support of Israeli hostages in Gaza that left at least eight injured was criminally charged by US prosecutors in Colorado.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: An Israeli flag fixed to a street sign as police stand by off Pearl Street on the scene of an attack in Boulder, Colorado, on June 1, 2025.

item.title: From AI to Nukes: Here’s What’s in the UK’s Big Defense Overhaul
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s government outlined a new defense strategy on Monday that aims to put a “stronger, more lethal” North Atlantic Treaty Organization at the forefront of British defense plans as the country boosts its nuclear deterrent, rebuilds munitions and weapons stockpiles and invests billions of pounds into technologically-advanced warfare methods.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Soldiers of the British Army prepare an artillery gun during a military exercise near Hohenfels, Germany.

item.title: Trump Plans to Tap Biden’s Green Bank to Make Billions in Loans
item.description: The Trump administration plans to use a $400 billion green bank the president once sought to kill to finance billions of dollars in loans for nuclear reactors, geothermal power and critical minerals, according to details of the administration’s fiscal year 2026 budget request.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference with Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Trump Condemns Boulder Attack, Blames Lax Immigration Policies
item.description: President Donald Trump condemned an attack in Boulder, Colorado that targeted a march in support of Israeli hostages held by Hamas and said he would work to remove the suspect in the attack from the US.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: A law enforcement official maintains police lines near the scene of an attack on the Pearl Street Mall in Boulder, Colorado on June 1.

item.title: Starmer Seeks Nuclear Build-Up in Sweeping UK Military Revamp
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer backed a sweeping overhaul of the British military yet refused to commit to the full extent of spending increases that experts said is necessary to protect the UK from growing global threats.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Tom Rees, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Members of staff during a visit byKeir Starmer to the BAE Systems' Govan facility, in Glasgow, on June 2.

item.title: Mexico Judicial Election Sees 13% Turnout in Historic Vote
item.description: The future of Mexico’s judiciary was decided by a small minority of voters after an unprecedented election of federal judges, including all members of the nation’s top court.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico’s president, casts a ballot at a polling station during the judicial elections in Mexico City, Mexico, on Sunday, June 1, 2025.

item.title: EU Votes to Curb China’s Access to Medical Device Procurement
item.description: The European Union agreed overwhelmingly to curb Chinese medical device manufacturers’ access to public procurement contracts in the bloc, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Agree on New Prisoner Swap But Fail to Reach Truce
item.description: Russia and Ukraine wrapped up a second round of talks in Istanbul that failed to bring the two sides closer to ending the war, but laid the groundwork for a new exchange of prisoners.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer, Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan, center, with Ukrainian and Russian delegations in Istanbul, on June 2. Photographer: Murat Gök/Turkish Foreign Ministry

item.title: Ukraine’s Brazen Drone Strike on Nuclear Bombers Alarms Moscow
item.description: Ukraine’s drone strike deep inside Russian territory left Kremlin officials angry and alarmed over the sudden vulnerability of a nuclear-capable air fleet far from the battlefield, according to people close to senior officials in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: A truck apparently used to release Ukrainian drones burns in the Irkutsk region, in a photo released by Irkutsk region Governor Igor Kobzev.

item.title: Trump Team Pushes for Xi Call as Trade Tensions Simmer
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are likely to speak this week, according to a Trump administration official, as the world’s two largest economies remain locked in trade turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI and Michele Spatari/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Wants to Sell 1 Million Barrel Reserve of Diesel Fuel
item.description: The Trump administration wants to put a 1 million barrel cache of diesel fuel on the market, saying the reserve meant to provide an emergency supply of home heating oil for the Northeast has never been used for its intended purpose.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter, Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: YurouGuan

item.title: US Aluminum and Steel Prices Surge as Trump Doubles Tariffs
item.description: Futures tracking aluminum and steel prices in the US surged after President Donald Trump said he will double tariffs on the metals this week.
item.dc:creator: Mark Burton

item.title: Supreme Court Leaves Intact ‘Assault Weapons’ Bans for Now
item.description: A divided US Supreme Court declined to consider a new expansion of constitutional gun rights, turning away challenges to a Maryland ban on so-called assault weapons and a Rhode Island prohibition on high-capacity magazines.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: A salesperson shows an AR-15 rifle to a customer at a store in Orem, Utah, U.S., on Thursday, March 25, 2021. Two mass shootings in one week are giving Democrats new urgency to pass gun control legislation, but opposition from Republicans in the Senate remains the biggest obstacle to any breakthrough in the long-stalled debate.

item.title: Matthei Gives Chile Vote Pledges a Reality Check on Fiscal Woes
item.description: Faced with an electoral campaign fought on two fronts — against the left and the hard right — Chile’s presidential front-runner Evelyn Matthei is trying to mark a difference not through sweeping promises, but by recognizing the cold, hard facts of a weak economy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Presidential candidate for the Independent Democratic Union party, Evelyn Matthei, speaks during an event in Santiago, Chile, on May 19.

item.title: Revved-Up Polish Assets Dip as Election Erodes Pro-EU Tilt
item.description: Polish stocks and bonds — among the world’s stand-out performers of 2025 — dipped after a nationalist unexpectedly won the presidential election, dealing a blow to the government.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski, Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: Poll workers empty the ballot boxes at a primary school before they are counted during the second round of the presidential elections in Gdansk, on June 1, 2025. Photo Mateusz SLODKOWSKI / AFP/Getty Images

item.title: EU Warns It Could Accelerate Retaliatory Tariffs Over US Duties
item.description: The European Union is preparing for another round of trade talks with the US and warned that it may speed up retaliatory measures if President Donald Trump follows through on his tariff threats, the latest of which includes a 50% levy on steel and aluminum imports.
item.dc:creator: Michal Kubala, Katharina Rosskopf

media:content.media:description: A container vessel in Copenhagen.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Conclude Talks After Kyiv Hits Bombers
item.description: Russia and Ukraine wrapped up their latest direct peace talks in Istanbul a day after Kyiv staged one of its boldest aerial attacks inside Russia, destroying long-range bombers and other aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer, Olesia Safronova

item.title: Philippines Aims to Cut Reliance on Vietnam for Rice
item.description: The Philippines, the world’s top rice importer, plans to look beyond its dominant supplier, Vietnam, to ensure steady supplies and competitive prices at home.
item.dc:creator: Neil Jerome Morales, Cliff Harvey Venzon

item.title: Nationalist Wins Poland’s Presidency in Setback for EU Ties
item.description: A nationalist candidate backed by Donald Trump won Poland’s presidential election, defeating the centrist mayor of Warsaw and complicating efforts to shift the nation back into the European Union mainstream.
item.dc:creator: Maciej Martewicz, Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki, center, with his wife Marta and their children during an election night rally in Warsaw, Poland, on June 1, 2025.

item.title: Ukraine Building Drone Hunters as Fight Moves Far Beyond Front
item.description: A battle is shaping up in the skies over Ukraine and Russia, as the ingenuity of drone engineers on both sides opens up new opportunities and threats far behind the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova, Aliaksandr Kudrytski

media:content.media:description: A technician prepares a Shrike drone at the Skyfall military technology company in Ukraine. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: MAGA-Backed Win in Poland Sends Europe a Warning
item.description: The revenge of “places that don’t matter” is increasingly palpable from Portugal to Poland.
item.dc:creator: Lionel Laurent

media:content.media:description: WARSAW, POLAND - JUNE 01: Karol Nawrocki, presidential candidate of the Law and Justice Party (PiS), stands on stage with his wife Marta as they gesture to supporters following the Polish presidential runoff election on June 01, 2025 in Warsaw, Poland. Today's election is a closely contested race between Nawrocki and Rafal Trzaskowski, the liberal mayor of Warsaw who is supported by Prime Minister Donald Tusk. The election is seen as a test of whether the government, with its centrist parliamentary coalition, can overcome the right-wing populism embodied by PiS. (Photo by Sean Gallup/Getty Images)

item.title: Emirates Reviews Russia Flights as Ukraine Expands Drone Use
item.description: The world’s largest long-haul carrier plans to review flights to Russia following Ukrainian drone attacks deep inside the country over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Palazzo, Guy Johnson

media:content.media:description: An Emirates Airline Airbus A380 aircraft at Dubai International Airport. Photographer: Christophe Viseux/Bloomberg

item.title: Polish Boxer-Turned-President Set for Showdown With Government
item.description: Karol Nawrocki has made a career out of fighting. An amateur boxing champion and self-confessed football hooligan, the historian-turned-politician has written books on anti-communist groups and organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Ojewska, Piotr Skolimowski

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki, center, at a rally during election night. Photographer: Marek Antoni Iwaczuk/SOPA Images/Getty Images

item.title: Reeves Says Tories Cost UK Taxpayer £1.4 Billion in Failed Covid Contracts
item.description: Deficient pandemic-era contracts for protective equipment cost the British taxpayer £1.4 billion ($1.9 billion), the UK’s Labour government said on Monday, blaming the former Conservative administration for “reckless handling” of public money.
item.dc:creator: Alex Morales

media:content.media:description: Boxes of discarded PPE in Calmore, UK.

item.title: Amazon Hit by German Warning Over Price Controls on Marketplace
item.description: Amazon.com Inc. was warned by Germany’s antitrust watchdog that price controls for retailers on its marketplace are likely to violate national and European Union laws.
item.dc:creator: Karin Matussek

media:content.media:description: Amazon packages ready for dispatch at a distribution center in Germany.

item.title: Romania Injects More Funds to Banks as Market Shortage Narrows
item.description: Romania’s central bank injected liquidity into domestic banks for a second week as it sought to further calm money markets after increased volatility during recent political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Romania's central bank in Bucharest. Photographer: Andrei Pungovschi/Bloomberg

item.title: MAGA Triumphs in Poland’s Presidential Election
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki, center, with his wife Marta and their children during an election night rally in Warsaw on June 1. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images Europe

item.title: Senate Begins Putting Its Stamp on Giant Trump Tax, Debt Limit Bill
item.description: Significant changes are in store for President Donald Trump’s signature $3.9 trillion tax-cut bill as the Senate begins closed-door talks this week on legislation that squeaked through the House by a single vote.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis, Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Senator Mike Crapo in Washington. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Plans to Offload National Park Sites, But States Don’t Want Them
item.description: The White House wants to trim the National Park Service budget by transferring some parks to state and tribal management. States say their resources are already tight.
item.dc:creator: Bobby Magill

media:content.media:description: An American alligator defends its mud hole during the dry season in Big Cypress National Preserve.

item.title: Bolsonaro’s Plan to Stage a Trumpian Comeback Might Save Lula’s Presidency
item.description: Jair Bolsonaro’s insistence he can pull off a Donald Trump-like comeback in Brazil’s looming election has paralyzed his fervent right-wing movement, effectively blocking the search for a successor to the ineligible former president.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Carvalho, Raphael Almeida Dos Santos, Beatriz Reis

media:content.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro
